intro: An unconventional path: from early IT skills to military discipline, until finding my way as a developer.

2008.title: Where It All Began
2008.subtitle: 14 years old | Brazil
2008.description: While most 14-year-olds were only worried about school and fun, I was already spending hours taking apart computers to understand how they worked. I got my first job at a neighborhood LAN house, where I started repairing machines that crashed in the middle of Counter-Strike matches.
2008.expanded: It was there, among network cables, burned motherboards, and impatient customers, that I discovered my calling: solving technical problems gave me a satisfaction that no other activity provided. Each recovered computer was a small victory. I worked in this field from 14 to 18, building a solid foundation of hardware and networking knowledge that I carry to this day.

2012.title: Discipline Forged
2012.subtitle: 18 years old | Brazilian Armed Forces
2012.description: At 18, I made a decision that would change my life: joining the Brazilian armed forces. The first year was in the combat squadron - an intense experience that tested all my physical and mental limits.
2012.expanded: Waking up at 4 AM, exhausting training, tactical exercises under scorching sun or torrential rain. I learned that the mind gives up long before the body, and that teamwork is not optional when lives depend on it. In the second year, I was assigned to the barracks' IT cell. It was a perfect bridge between my two passions: military discipline and technology. I repaired computers, managed Linux systems, installed printers via terminal - skills that few soldiers had.

2013.title: Two Worlds, One Mission
2013.subtitle: Anhanguera University | Systems Analysis
2013.description: Even with the intense routine of military life, I knew I needed a solid academic background in technology. I started my degree in Systems Analysis and Development, determined to balance both worlds.
2013.expanded: It wasn't easy. I studied during breaks, on days off, late into the night. While fellow soldiers rested, I was poring over algorithms, databases, and programming logic. This experience taught me real time management - not the theory from productivity books, but the practice of someone who had no choice but to make it work.

2017.title: Beyond Borders
2017.subtitle: France | Légion Étrangère
2017.description: In 2017, I made the boldest decision of my life: leaving Brazil and joining the legendary Légion Étrangère - the French Foreign Legion. One of the most rigorous and respected military forces in the world.
2017.expanded: The selection process is brutal: out of hundreds of candidates, only a fraction is accepted. I arrived in France without speaking French, without knowing anyone, only with the conviction that I wanted to test my limits. The Legion taught me that we are capable of much more than we imagine. I lived with people from over 50 nationalities, learned to communicate beyond words, to solve problems when there's no instruction manual.

2020.title: The Reunion with Code
2020.subtitle: France | Rocketseat Bootcamps
2020.description: After years dedicated to military career, in 2020 I decided to return to my original passion: programming. The world had changed - React, Node.js, TypeScript were the new standards. I needed to completely update myself.
2020.expanded: I dove headfirst into Rocketseat bootcamps. It was months of intense study: waking up early, studying before work, continuing at night. The military discipline I had developed was my greatest ally. While many dropped out mid-course, I treated each module as a mission to be accomplished.

2021.title: From Theory to Practice
2021.subtitle: Freelancer | Global Clients
2021.description: In 2021, I took the most important step: I started working as a freelance developer. It wasn't easy to get the first clients - after all, I had technical knowledge but zero professional portfolio.
2021.expanded: I started accepting small projects, sometimes for below-market rates, just to build real experience. The advantage of being a freelancer is that you're forced to master the entire stack - there's no colleague to delegate to. From design in Figma to deploy on AWS, I did everything. This made me a complete developer.

2024.title: The Next Level
2024.subtitle: Amiltone | Enterprise Consulting
2024.description: In 2024, I took another step in my career evolution: I joined Amiltone, a French IT consulting firm with high-level enterprise projects.
2024.expanded: I left the freelance world to work in structured teams, with mature processes and scale challenges. My unconventional trajectory became my differential: I bring military discipline to meet deadlines, the Legion's adaptability to work with any team, the freelancer mindset to deliver with autonomy.
